ygData.subject: A friend indeed.

The wind blew gently, but Tavatron paid it little notice. She gazed silently 
forward, her head slightly raised. She thought she heard something�

It was nothing. Nothing at all. Who was she kidding? The entire run to this 
secluded spot she thought she had heard a �bot following her. As the wind 
shifted and changed direction it brought a familiar scent to fem �bot. A 
scent that vanished with the dying wind. There was no one behind her. She 
had rown used to Dinobot�s constant companionship. Tavatron absentmindedly 
began flicking small pebbles and dirt clods over the cliff�s edge. She began 
timing their descent, until they were no longer visible.

*flick* �3 �2 �1

*flick* �5 �4 �3 �

Tavatron whipped her head around. There was definitely someone there� A 
small smile was all that betrayed her solemn appearance. The brush behind 
her continued to rustle softly and the heavy breathing of a seemingly 
injured �bot echoed in her ears. Her augmented hearing had picked up 
something a while ago. Well, maybe he did care enough to follow her. That 
didn�t mean she had to acknowledge his presence� yet. Again, a small smile 
was etched on her dark muzzle. Her head was facing the forest again, the one 
that lay below the cliff. It reminded her of peaceful times. Of times when 
her biggest concern was avoiding the cops. Now, however, things had changed. 
She wasn�t running from cops anymore, she was surviving a war.

She never had much of a childhood. She had always been on the move. Ever 
since her parents� s-since�

A heavy sigh was all that penetrated the growing silence. She had never 
really known them, so why did she miss them so slaggin� much?! Not too long 
ago �bots would call her callous, cold-hearted, perhaps even a little� dark. 
If only they had known. But that would mean talking about things she had 
long since repressed. She rarely let herself get close to other �bots. It 
just made the pain of losing them greater.

She had gone to great lengths to avoid much contact with other �bots. But 
she had made a mistake. She�d let her guard down, and look what happened.

*Look what happened indeed�*

The wind picked up again, carrying with it the familiar scent she had 
noticed earlier.

*you made a friend.*

Tavatron slowly got to her feet. Her muscles had stiffened from the long 
run. She cautiously stretched her right hindleg, then her left.  Next she 
did a full body stretch, all the while listening as Dinobot emerged from the 
forest. His breathing was labored. Actually, she was surprised he was 
capable of keeping pace with her in his current state. Tavatron finished her 
stretching just as he spoke.

His voice sounded pained, maybe a little annoyed. Tavatron breathed a sigh 
of relief. She was beginning to worry she had done something she would 
regret for the rest of her life. Slag, he could attack her honor for the 
rest of eternity, she�d still be his friend. Who was she kidding? Of course 
it had hurt her deeply when he said things like that, but only because she 
cared about what he thought. When he said she was no warrior she had begun 
to doubt herself. Something she had rarely done.

Tavatron stretched her front paw one more time before transforming and 
turning to face a weary Dinobot. Judging from the way he held his side his 
injuries were still plaguing  him. He had come after, she thought he 
wouldn�t have bothered. Perhaps she had misjudged him:

"Well, I�m glad to see you�re up and about."
